Title: Replacing Woodrow Wilson; Effort Here Would Restore Prague's Long-Gone Monument to Democracy
Abstract: For 13 years in the early decades of the 20th century, a larger-than-life bronze statue of Woodrow Wilson stood in front of the main train station in Prague as a reminder of the 28th U.S. president's role in creating an independent Czechoslovakia out of the wreckage of World War I. Now, with the help of Robert Doubek, a federal employee with Czech roots who was instrumental in getting the Vietnam Veterans Memorial built, and Paul Beckmann, an architect from Alexandria, a memorial to Wilson is slated to rise again in Prague in 2012. Because Wilson's father was a minister, sculptor Albin Polasek depicted Wilson's hands outstretched in much the way a Presbyterian minister would give a blessing.
